cab.content: Printed for the Cabinet. July 1923.SECRET.CP. 333 (23).CABINET.19SPECIAL REPORT ON UNEMPLOYMENT. No. 96. Period ended July 13, 1923. The number of persons registered at the Employment Exchanges as whollyunemployed at the 9th July was 1,189,133, a decrease of 2,217 on the previousweek. il . - ' POSITION IN CHIEF INDUSTRIES.COAL-MINING. The position in Lancashire and the Midlands has continued to be satisfactory,but in the latter district, as well as in Yorkshire and Durham, there have beenindications of depression. The situation in Scotland and Wales has continuedsatisfactory. The Bristol fields have continued active, and the Forest of Dean, after IRON AND STEEL. No improvement has occurred in the position in the Midlands, unemployment having" remained heavy, with a discouraging outlook. The depression in Scotland has continued, and prospects are uncertain. Unemployment on the North-East Coast has become more acute. In North Wales employment has continued good, but in South Wales there has been a diminution in output. SHIPBUILDING AND SHIP-REPAIRING. Employment at most of the yards on the South-West Coast continues to be indifferent, The industrial dispute among the boilermakers has adversely affected this industry, particularly in Scotland and the North of England. Conditions are unsettled on the Merseyside, where upwards of 6,000 operatives are unemployed. On the other hand, a perceptible improvement has been reported from Welsh centres. ENGINEERING. Trade is quiet in London and the Home Counties. The improvement in the South-Western Counties continues, but is unevenly spread. In the Midlands, the motor and cycle section has, on the whole, been fair, business at some centres being very brisk. In general engineering there has been a tendency towards improvement.In Yorkshire and the North of England the slight improvement has been maintained.The textile section in Lancashire has been slack generally, and in general engineeringthe position is not satisfactory, but there is promise of increased activity. Thedepression in Scotland has continued. In Wales the general situation shows some improvement.SUMMARY OF UNEMPLOYMENT SITUATION.a slight relapse, is again busy. TEXTILES. Cotton. In Lancashire the curtailment of production on an extended scale byspinners of American yarns continues. Employment in the fine yarn section has,however, continued good. The depression among weavers is still acute. There is no sign of relief in the depression existing in Yorkshire. Hosiery, Woollen and Worsted. The position of the hosiery trade in theMidlands has altered but little; but the change in the weather conditions is expectedto lead to seasonal improvement. In Yorkshire unemployment has again increasedamong operatives in the woollen and worsted industry. In Scotland no material change has occurred, and prospects are no brighter. Lace.-Unemployment has increased in the Midlands. In the South-western counties unemployment has increased at both Exeter and Chard. Silk.-Although fluctuations in employment have taken place at certain centres in the Midlands, activity is mainly restricted to artificial silk manufacture. Jute. Trade is quiet, but the outlook is a little more hopeful.BUILDING. Employment has been good generally, with a persistent demand for skilledoperatives.BOOT AND SHOE. The slackness at Norwich has continued. The depression in the South-western counties has continued except at Bath, where trade is improving. A slightimprovement has occurred at some centres in the Midlands.CLOTHING. The slackness in the tailoring, dressmaking and millinery trades has continued at most of the centres in London, the Home Counties, the South-Western counties and the Midlands. In the wholesale clothing section trade has been very good in theMidlands, and the outlook in the South-Western Counties is more hopeful, but in yorkshire a tendency towards decline is noticeable.POTTERY AND GLASS. Unemployment at the principal pottery centres in the Midlands has tended toincrease, and the prospects are not encouraging.TRANSPORT. The industrial dispute among dock workers has hindered activity at some ofthe principal ports in the country. Certain ports on the North-East Coast whichhave not been affected by the dispute have, however, been very busy in connectionwith the importation of timber. Activity at Swansea has declined owing to quietnessin the tinplate trade.C. A. MONTAGUE BARLOW, Ministry of Labour. I.-DETAILED UNEMPLOYMENT FIGURES. 1. GENERAL PERCENTAGE OF UNEMPLOYMENT. [NOTE. SUMMARY OF ACTION TAKEN. [From Autumn 1920 onwards.] Cabinet Unemployment Committee. The prospect of a severe trade depression first became evident in the early autumn of 1920. On the 13th August, 1920, the then Cabinet appointed a CabinetUnemployment Committee to consider the whole question and devise means for relieving unemployment. This Committee continued to function till October 1922.The present Government appointed a Cabinet Unemployment Committee on the1st November, 1922. (A.) Unemployment Insurance. An Unemployment Insurance Act of general scope came into operation on the8th November, 1920. The Act applied compulsory insurance against unemployment to 12,000,000 persons as compared with 4,000,000 previously. Subsequent amendingActs modified the conditions as regards rates of benefit, extended the periods ofbenefit and increased the contributions. As from November 1921 the unemployed workers' Dependants' (Temporary Provision) Act, 1921, made temporary provision)for grants in respect of wives, dependent husbands and children, and imposed aspecial levy to provide for these grants. The Unemployment Insurance Act, 1922,amalgamated the dependants' grants with Unemployment Benefit, and the speciallevy with the Unemployment Insurance contributions, and extended until June 1923the special periods during which benefit might be drawn. The authority to borrow money from the Treasury was increased to 30,000,000. By the UnemploymentInsurance Act, 1923, which came into operation on the 12th April, 1923, the specialperiods for the.payment of benefit have been extended to October 1923. special provision has also been made by this Act for the following year to October 1924.TABLE showing amount paid out in Unemployment Benefit (including Benefit in respect of Dependants), and the Contributions during the period from the 8th November, 1920, to the 7th July, 1923, - 1. (B.) Emergency Works and other Measures. A full statement of the measures taken in the autumn of 1920 and of the latermeasures from autumn 1921 onwards has been set out in previous issues of thisReport. At least 300,000 men have had employment on these schemes at various times, and at the present time over 134,000 men are employed, exclusive of the workprovided for men in ancillary occupations and the effect"of the Export credits scheme. ' ' . ... (C.) Extensions of Remedial Measures during the Winter 1922-23. Some of the measures comprised in (B) above are still in operation, e.g., pastsanctions of grants by the Unemployment Grants Committee and the Ministry ofTransport. The Export Credits Scheme continues, and schemes approved under theTrade Facilities Act are in progress. In June 1922, the Unemployment Grants Committee and the Ministry of Transportissued circular letters to Local Authorities inviting them to submit schemes for works of public utility, which, with assistance from State funds, might be undertaken for^ the relief of unemployment in their respective areas. Approved schemes areassisted by grants made on the same bases as heretofore. In the case of schemesassisted by the Unemployment Grants Committee,' particulars of grants already sanctioned are set out below. [10378] E 3 G . In "September, 1922, the Ministry of Agriculture and Fisheries issued circular f letters to County Councils (except the London County Council) and Drainage I Authorities, inviting them to submit schemes of land drainage which, if approved j might be assisted on fundamentally the same conditions as those applicable in the case^ of schemes assisted during the previous year. All applications were to be received in the case of. Drainage Authorities on or before December 1, 1922 and in the case of County Councils (Agricultural Committees) on or before December 16, 1922. County Councils were also circulated with regard to schemes for the supply of water to farms, the conditions of assistance from the Ministry oi Agriculture and Fisheries remaining substantially the same as the previous winter, with the exception that the Ministry, instead of' advancing the whole cost ot any scheme and recovering a proportion from the owners concerned, will make grants to cover part only of the total cost of each scheme. Further circulars, issued to 1 County Councils and Drainage Authorities on the 5th and 6th December respectively, f notified the extension of the date up to which applications might be received to the 1 13th January, 1923, and invited the submission of additional schemes. The time for f receiving applications was further extended provisionally to the 10th February, 1 1923. Particulars of grants sanctioned and of the number of men employed to date 1 are shown below (see III, item 6). On the 30th November, 1922, the Minister of Labour, in the House of Common outlined the manner in which measures taken by the late Government would continued and extended. The additional sums promised in extension of existing funds are set out below : Unemployment Grants Committee (for grants on the basis of 60 per cent, of Wages Bill) ... ... ... ..... 600,000 Land Drainage ... ... ... :.. 170,000 Afforestation ... ... ............. 100,000 Acceleration of Government contracts Office of Works .......... 375,000 General Post Office ... ... 946,000 - 1,321,000 It was also then announced that guarantees under the Trade Facilities AclScheme would be made available up to 50,000,000 ( 25,000,000 extra); that the Export Credits Scheme would be extended if necessary; and that the Local Authorities' concerned would be asked to co:operate in putting in hand the Manchester-Liverpool Road, which would involve an expenditure of about 3,000,000, half of it from the Road Fund. In December 1922, the Unemployment Grants Committee issued a furthei circular letter to Local Authorities inviting them to submit schemes suitable foi assistance on the basis of 60 per cent, of the Wages Bill, i.e., works the cost of which is normally defrayed out of revenue and not by loan. The conditions under which grants may be sanctioned are substantially the same as those previously in force, except that in the case of Rural Districts the Committee have discretion to allow, where clearly necessary, a modification of the conditions regarding the giving ol preference to 75 per cent, ex-service men and the engagement of labour through the Employment Exchanges. ' On the 12th December, 1922, the Minister of Labour, in the House of Commons, further announced that, in addition to the acceleration of contracts by the Post Office and Office of Works, previously described, the Admiralty would accelerate miscellaneous works to a total of about 365,000; whilst the Home Office would pui in hand certain accelerated building work, together with repairs to buildings, including Police Stations. On. the 13th December, 1922, the Forestry Commission issued a press notice to the effect that forestry grants were available for the relief of unemployment on the same general conditions as those applicable to grants made during the previous winter. The sum of 100,000 referred to above is to be used partly for this purpose and partly for the purpose of relief schemes in Crown Forests and for additional work in the Commission^ Forests. By the Trade Facilities and Loans Guarantee Act, 1922. (Session 2), enacted on the loth December, 1922, formal sanction was given for the increase of the aggregate capital amount of loans the principal or interest of which mav be guaranteed under the Trade Facilities Act, 1921, from 25,000,000 to 50,000,000. On the 15th February, 1923, the Minister of Labour, in the House of Commons, announced an extension of 5,600,000 in the amount available for grants in respect of approved road works by the Ministry of Transport.
